moves.1. c4: As in our last game, my opponent chose the English but I responded differently.
moves.1... e5 2. g3 Nf6 3. Bg2 Be7 4. a3: Seems a slightly odd response to ...Be7 but I suppose it prepares Queenside expansion coupled with Queenside fianchetto.
moves.4... O-O 5. Nc3 c6: This move demonstrates the old observation that every move has its advantages and disadvantages: the pawn advance contests control of d5 and b5 but deprives the QN of its most active square
moves.6. d3 d6: I felt the need to prepare for the development of my Queenside but couldn't yet commit to ...d5 because the sums didn't work..
moves.7. Nf3 Nbd7 8. O-O Rb8 9. b4 b5 10. cxb5: From my point of view, the first mysterious move of the game.  It defends e4 while blocking in White's fianchettoed bishop and appears to prepare g4 but also exposes the K on the g1-a7 diagonal, not that Black can exploit it.
moves.16... Rbc8 17. Bh3: ? So Black immediately invites White to reactivate his B.
moves.17... Rc4: ? Advancing a Rook to no particular purpose is always risky
moves.18. Be3 Bc8 19. Bg2 Be6: At least I've redeveloped my B where it is no longer biting on granite.
moves.20. Rc1 Rfc8 21. Rxc4 Rxc4: ? Recapturing with the wrong piece.  As a general principle it is always better to have the heavy artillery behind the lighter fighters.  This R soon becomes embarrassed, losing me the game.
moves.22. Qd2 d5: I thought I was winning with this move...
moves.23. exd5 Nxd5 24. Bc5: This move seals in the errant Rook while assaulting the Q.
moves.24... Qc7 25. e4: Not only does this attack the Knight but it also cuts off the Rook's lateral options and opens up a potential line of attack for the Bg2 from f1.
moves.25... Nb6 26. Rd1: Now there's a serious back-row mate threat to be followed by an attack on that errant R.
moves.26... f6 27. Bf1 Rxc5 28. Qd8+ Kf7 29. b: Black's chances seem to lie in promoting a Queenside pawn, so this is logical pawn-grabbing.
moves.34. Rd6 Qa2+ 35. Kg3 c3: ?? This seems to throw a valuable pawn away.
moves.36. Qc7+ Kg6 37. Qe7: But White finds a more direct attack.
moves.37... Bf7: ? Given White's response, this move is inadequate.  It was probably better to advance the c-pawn again, giving up the B.
moves.38. Qxe5: !  I'd completely missed this capture, exploiting the pin on my 3rd rank.  Now mate in 1 is threatened (Qh5).
? Overlooking another pin on the 3rd rank.  It was probably impossible to avoid imminent mate but to overlook the immediate was unforgiveable.  If I'd played this knowing I was going to be mated next move I wouldn't mind ...  At least he took a couple of minutes to see it himself!
